newsitem.title: USA: U.S. 1996 current account gap highest in nine years.
newsitem.headline: U.S. 1996 current account gap highest in nine years.

text.p: The U.S. current account deficit, the broadest measure of the nation's trade performance, climbed to its highest level in nine years in 1996, the Commerce Department said on Thursday.
The total deficit in trade in goods and services, in investment income and in so-called unilateral transfers like direct grants to other countries rose to $165.1 billion from $148.2 billion in 1995.
Department officials said it was the biggest gap in total trade for any year since 1987, when there was a $167.4 billion deficit.
The current account is the country's most important trade statistic because it measures trade not only in merchandise and services, but also investment flows between countries.

In the three months from October through December, the deficit decreased to $41.4 billion from $47.9 billion in the third quarter. But that was still well above Wall Street analysts' forecast of a $38.8 billion fourth-quarter shortfall.

In the final three months last year, the deficits in goods and services and in investment income declined from the third quarter. But the department noted there was a bump upward in unilateral transfers because of higher U.S. government grants to Israel.

The fourth-quarter deficit in goods and services trade fell to $26.3 billion from $34.3 billion in the third quarter, while the shortfall on investment income was down to $2.4 billion from $4.1 billion as U.S. assets abroad increased strongly.
But unilateral transfers climbed to $12.6 billion in the fourth quarter from $9.5 billion in the third quarter because of the increase in grants to Israel.
For the full year, the department said that deficits in goods and services, in investment income and in unilateral transfers all increased from 1995.

There were net capital inflows to the United States last year of $218.2 billion, up from $116.6 billion in 1995. "An acceleration in foreign assets in the United States accounted for the larger net capital inflows," the department said.
Purchases of U.S. Treasury securities, other types of securities and direct foreign investments in the United States were sharply higher last year than in 1995, Commerce said.
